item.title: Top Kremlin Mouthpiece Warns of 'Inevitable' War With USA Over Ukraine...
item.description:
www.yahoo.com
John MacDougall/AFP via Getty ImagesAll-out cyber-warfare, nation-wide forced black-outs, and the targeted disruption of internet services‚Äîfor one of the Kremlin‚Äôs top propagandists, all of those tactics are fair-game in what she describes as a fated war-to-come against the U.S.‚ÄúWar [with the U.S.] is inevitable,‚Äù declared Margarita Simonyan, editor-in-chief of the state-funded media outlets, RT and Sputnik, who believes the conflict will break out when, not if, Putin moves to seize more territory from Ukraine.As Russia‚Äôs military buildup on Ukraine‚Äôs doorstep mounts, Kremlin loyalists have been urging for even more overt aggression and bloodshed in the campaign to annex Ukraine‚Äôs Donbas region. The only thing standing in the way, they say, is U.S. support for their beleaguered neighbor.The club of G7 nations, which includes the U.S., issued a joint statement on Monday demanding an end to Russia‚Äôs troop build up on the border with the disputed territory of Donbas in eastern Ukraine, reminiscent of the build-up prior to Russia‚Äôs annexation of Crimea in 2014. The U.S. underlined those words by deploying two warships to the Black Sea.On Tuesday, Russia‚Äôs deputy foreign minister Sergei Ryabkov threatened retaliation. ‚ÄúWe warn the United States that it will be better for them to stay far away from Crimea and our Black Sea coast. It will be for their own good,‚Äù he said.The escalation was foreshadowed on state television‚Äôs Sunday Evening with Vladimir Soloviev over the weekend. Simonyan explained that it was time for Russia to gear up for a showdown against the U.S., and prophesized a kind of war driven by hacking, the forced disruption of internet access, the shutting down of power supplies, and an all-out offensive on U.S. infrastructure.‚ÄúI do not believe that this will be a large-scale hot war, like World War II, and I do not believe that there will be a long Cold War. It will be a war of the third type: the cyber war,‚Äù said Simonyan.She warned that‚Äîin this theoretical battle‚Äîthe U.S. would plot to cut off the electricity of entire Russian cities. In turn, she speculated, Moscow would be able to force a black-out in Florida or Harlem at the flip of a switch.‚ÄúIn conventional war, we could defeat Ukraine in two days,‚Äù Simonyan said, ‚Äúbut it will be another kind of war. We‚Äôll do it, and then [the U.S.] will respond by turning off power to [the Russian city] Voronezh,‚Äù she said.The top RT editor asserted that ‚Äú[Russia] needs to be ready for this war, which is unavoidable, and of course it will start in Ukraine,‚Äù arguing that the Kremlin is ‚Äúinvincible where conventional war is concerned, but forget about conventional war... it will be a war of infrastructures, and here we have many vulnerabilities.‚ÄùHer solution consists of Stalin-type measures to eliminate ‚Äúvulnerabilities‚Äù in the run-up to another escalation, emphasizing the need for a hack-proof, government-controlled internet. ‚ÄúWe still don‚Äôt have a sovereign internet, but god-willing, we will,‚Äù she said.She wholeheartedly endorsed a suggestion from Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the leader of one of Russia‚Äôs Liberal Democratic Party, who argued that all of Russia‚Äôs opposition must be eliminated by May 1, 2021. With imprisoned opposition leader Alexei Navalny on a hunger strike‚Äîand suffering from severe health ailments after being denied appropriate medical treatment‚Äîthe Kremlin seems to be firmly set on that course.Simonyan argued that once Russia minimizes its vulnerabilities and renders Putin‚Äôs opposition powerless‚Äîwhich she argued could happen in a matter of months‚Äîthe Kremlin will finally be ready to annex Ukraine‚Äôs eastern region.‚ÄúI‚Äôve been agitating and even demanding that we take Donbas. We need to patch up our vulnerabilities as fast as we can, and then we can do whatever we want,‚Äù she boldly proclaimed. The host, Vladimir Soloviev, wholeheartedly agreed: ‚ÄúWe only lose if we do nothing.‚Äù He argued that by absorbing parts of Ukraine‚Äîor the entire country‚ÄîRussia would be able to remove the zone of American influence further away from its borders.As one of the Kremlin‚Äôs most valued propagandists, Margarita Simonyan is notoriously close to the Russian president and has received multiple awards directly from Vladimir Putin. After accepting one such award in 2019, Simonyan thanked Putin ‚Äúfor the most important reward in life‚Ä¶ this honor to serve one‚Äôs Motherland.‚ÄùHer ‚Äúservice‚Äù has involved RT and Sputnik-driven disinformation operations aimed at influencing the 2016 U.S. presidential election, which she often boasts about by pointing to the inclusion of her name in various U.S. intelligence reports.Russia‚Äôs recent cyberspace activities seem to serve as good practice for the ‚Äúinevitable war‚Äù foreshadowed by Simonyan.Last year, six Russian intelligence officers were criminally charged by the U.S. for using the world‚Äôs most destructive malware to force blackouts in Ukraine and damage the critical infrastructure of multiple countries, which caused nearly $1 billion in losses. On Monday, hackers operating from Russia targeted France's homeschooling platform.The Kremlin is prepared to intensify its offensive against the West, but fears of the retaliation that would follow. The idea of a bullet-proof ‚Äúsovereign internet‚Äù‚Äîcompletely under government control within Russian borders‚Äîis already on the books, with Moscow having introduced the idea as a preventative measure against retaliatory hacking attempts from other nations.Simonyan argued that Russia will surely be able to exploit the U.S.‚Äôs ‚Äúcatastrophic‚Äù educational standards, and referred to American military analysts and specialists as incompetent and stupid. She heartily laughed about news that more than 200,000 U.S. service members experienced hearing loss due to defective earplugs.‚ÄúWe can never come to any agreements with [Americans],‚Äù Simonyan said, arguing that instead, Russia can just as easily defeat the U.S. in a cyberspace war.She added, mockingly: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt even need the nukes.‚ÄùRead more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day. item.title: Eyes Potential Threat From China's Digital Yuan Plans...
item.description:
finance.yahoo.com
(Bloomberg) -- The Biden administration is stepping up scrutiny of China‚Äôs plans for a digital yuan, with some officials concerned the move could kick off a long-term bid to topple the dollar as the world‚Äôs dominant reserve currency, according to people familiar with the matter.Now that China‚Äôs digital-currency efforts are gathering momentum, officials at the Treasury, State Department, Pentagon and National Security Council are bolstering their efforts to understand the potential implications, the people said.American officials are less worried about an immediate challenge to the current structure of the global financial system, but are eager to understand how the digital yuan will be distributed, and whether it could also be used to work around U.S. sanctions, the people said on the condition of anonymity.A Treasury spokeswoman declined to comment. A National Security Council spokeswoman did not reply to a request for comment.The People‚Äôs Bank of China has rolled out trial issuance of a digital yuan in cities across the country, putting it on track to be the first major central bank to issue a virtual currency. A broader roll-out is expected for the Winter Olympics in Beijing next February, giving the effort international exposure.Many key details of the digital yuan are still in flux, including specifics on how it would be distributed. China‚Äôs recent establishment of a joint venture with SWIFT, the messaging nexus through which most cross-border settlements pass through today, suggests it is possible a digital yuan could work within the current financial architecture rather than outside of it.U.S. officials are reassured that China‚Äôs intentions aren‚Äôt to use the digital yuan to evade American sanctions, according to people familiar with the matter. The dollar‚Äôs current dominance in cross-border transactions gives the U.S. Treasury the power to cut off much of a business or even a country‚Äôs access to the global financial system.China‚Äôs officials have said the main intentions of the digital yuan are to replace banknotes and coins, to reduce the incentive to use cryptocurrencies and to complement the current private-sector run electronic payments system -- dominated by Ant Group Co.‚Äôs Alipay and Tencent Holdings Ltd.‚Äôs WeChat Pay. The PBOC has been working for years on the digital yuan, also called the e-CNY, having set up a specialist research team in 2014.Here‚Äôs How a Central Bank Digital Currency Could Work: Chart‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄúTo provide a backup or redundancy for the retail payment system, the central bank has to step up‚Äù and provide digital-currency services, Mu Changchun, the director of the PBOC‚Äôs digital-currency research institute, said at an event last month.Beyond seeking a backup to privately run e-payments, Chinese regulators have more broadly been expanding their oversight of the country‚Äôs digital champions. Ant Group was told by Beijing to become a financial holding company, which will be regulated more like a bank. China also imposed a $2.8 billion antitrust fine on Ant‚Äôs affiliate Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.Read More: Ant to Be Financial Holding Firm in Overhaul Forced by ChinaThe PBOC is also examining the potential for using the digital yuan in cross-border payments, launching a project studying the issue with a unit of the Bank for International Settlements along with the United Arab Emirates, Thailand and Hong Kong‚Äôs monetary authority.The Biden administration isn‚Äôt currently planning to take any action to counter longer-term threats from China‚Äôs digital currency, the people familiar with the discussions said. However, China‚Äôs plans have given renewed impetus to efforts to consider the creation of a digital dollar, they said.Members of Congress have also been increasingly interested in a digital dollar, aware of China‚Äôs moves, and asked Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen about the issue in hearings earlier this year.Powell: Need for Digital Dollar Is an Issue for Congress, PublicPowell said in February the Fed was looking ‚Äúvery carefully‚Äù at a digital dollar. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to be the first. We need to get it right.‚ÄùYellen has signaled interest in research into the viability of a digital dollar, a shift from a lack of enthusiasm under her predecessor, Steven Mnuchin.‚ÄúIt makes sense for central banks to be looking at‚Äù issuing sovereign digital currencies, she said at a virtual conference in February. Yellen said a digital version of the dollar could help address hurdles to financial inclusion in the U.S. among low-income households.A recent report from the U.S. Director of National Intelligence said the extent of the threat of any foreign digital currency to the dollar‚Äôs centrality in the global financial system ‚Äúwill depend on the regulatory rules that are established.‚ÄùChina‚Äôs currency makes up little more than 2% of global foreign exchange reserves compared with nearly 60% for the U.S. dollar. Policy decisions, rather than technical developments, will also be necessary to push forward yuan internationalization, as China maintains a strict regime of capital controls.China‚Äôs financial system is too ‚Äúfragile and weak‚Äù to pose a real threat to the dollar‚Äôs status as the world‚Äôs reserve currency, according to Mark Sobel, U.S. chairman for the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum.‚ÄúAt the end of the the day the markets have more confidence in the Fed‚Äù than China‚Äôs central bank, said Sobel, a former senior U.S. Treasury official for international matters.(Adds reference to China‚Äôs regulatory measures in 10th paragraph.)For more articles like this, please visit us at bloomberg.comSubscribe now to stay ahead with the most trusted business news source.¬©2021 Bloomberg L.P.

item.title: Brits Get Morning Drunk in the Snow to Celebrate Grand Reopening...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
ITV NewsIt‚Äôs been a long, cold, lonely winter in England.So, as four months of a nationwide lockdown finally came to an end, nothing was going to stop people from enjoying a refreshing pint of beer at the crack of dawn on a Monday morning‚Äînot even driving rain, freezing temperatures, and some pretty unseasonal snowfall.Pubs started serving outdoors again as part of a reopening plan that also covers indoor gym sessions, swimming pools, non-essential shops, beauty salons, and, for those who have been gagging to see some sad animals, zoos. Prime Minister Boris Johnson had urged people to ‚Äúbehave responsibly‚Äù with their new freedoms, but didn‚Äôt explicitly say they shouldn‚Äôt get drunk in the snow before having breakfast.One pub in the town of Huddersfield was swamped when it opened at the stroke of midnight. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt even know if anyone was going to come,‚Äù said the pub landlord fittingly named Ian Snowball. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in Huddersfield, it‚Äôs midnight, it‚Äôs freezing cold‚Äîbut look, everyone has come.‚ÄùIf you thought you were starting early today‚Ä¶ üçªThese drinkers in Huddersfield braved the snow to enjoy a beer garden pint at midnight ‚ùÑÔ∏èhttps://t.co/UASiR7bXEv pic.twitter.com/i2O79eocSR‚Äî BBC Breakfast (@BBCBreakfast) April 12, 2021 One drinker commented matter-of-factly: ‚ÄúIt was snowing earlier but I was still going to come out, I just put my coat on.‚Äù Another, sitting in a thick jacket next to an icy-looking gin and tonic, made the fair point: ‚ÄúAfter 14 months of not going anywhere, except funerals, it‚Äôs a great place.‚ÄùSky News reported that 50 pub-goers headed to the Fox On The Hill pub in south London this morning. The most emotional was perhaps Tony Blake, 59, who gushed to the news network: ‚ÄúI am so happy that it‚Äôs open again, it‚Äôs unbelievable, I‚Äôm so happy.‚Äù Student Sasha Carrington, 19, said she planned to stay there for the entire freezing cold day, explaining: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got our layers on, thermals, we‚Äôre going to stay outside.‚ÄùPippa Ingram, 51, and Sue Bell, 55, celebrated a chilly seaside pint in Kent, with Ingram describing her first sip in detail. ‚ÄúAbsolutely delicious,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not gonna last long at all! That is banging.‚Äù Back in Huddersfield, in footage timestamped at 8.17 a.m., a woman identified only as Sandy was seen having pints with her friends, and she told Good Morning Britain: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that cold after a while when you‚Äôre sat in the sun.‚ÄùAs pub gardens reopen from today, @NickDixonITV talks to some people who have enjoyed a pint since 8am this morning.They discuss how happy they are to be back in pub gardens following the lockdown.Watch GMB üëâ https://t.co/6iQ6ebeOEQ pic.twitter.com/W0yAai1tGD‚Äî Good Morning Britain (@GMB) April 12, 2021 One pub in Coventry appears to have taken things slightly too far. Videos posted online showed more than 100 people lining the street outside the Oak Inn after it had publized its grand plans to open a massive outdoor space with heaters, marquees and blankets. The pub is now under investigation for its ‚Äúunmanageable amounts of visitors.‚ÄùBut, largely, the grand reopening has been welcomed as a major landmark‚Äîparticularly following the success of the Britain‚Äôs vaccine rollout, which has many hoping that there won‚Äôt be another lockdown. Nicholas Hair, landlord of the Kentish Belle in south-east London, told BBC News that there was a ‚Äúsense of celebration‚Äù in the country, adding: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping this is a sort of rebirth, and that we‚Äôre reopen for the foreseeable.‚ÄùAs for Boris himself, government sources confirmed that the prime minister received a long-awaited haircut on Monday‚Äîbut his planned trip to the pub has been cancelled out of respect for the late Prince Philip.Read more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day.
